pull_request.title: `@remotion/renderer`: Support the case of stride != width * 3 when rotating a video file

issue.title: Split up `setPort()` option
issue.body:
Currrently the `Config.setPort()` option sets the port for the Remotion Studio but also for rendering.
Now that you render from within the studio that leads to a conflict.

We should split it up to `Config.setStudioPort()` and `Config.setRendererPort()`. `Config.setPort()` should get a `@deprecated` JSDoc command but for now set both ports still.

The `--port` flag should set the Studio port when running the `remotion studio` command, but the renderer port when using any other  command.

comment.body:
Absolutely!

Thanks a lot for stepping up! 😊 🙌

issue.title: Create a native buffering state
issue.body:
If a video, audio or something else needs to load, the video will right now just keep on playing and Remotion needs to do time-shift-correction afterwards if the video has shifted.

We should introduce a native buffer state where the Player / Studio can briefly pause and resume the video in sync.

Similar to delayRender(), but during Preview. Something like delayPlayback(), and maybe later we can make a function which delays both render and playback.

I've heard a lot of user stories which gives me a good idea of what's needed, so I am going to start implementing this myself.

issue.title: Port busy issue with PowerShell in VS Code on Windows
issue.body:
```
╭─ Starting render 
│ (1/3) ╭───────────────────╮ Bundled code 2122ms
╰─  Failed to render
Error: Error while getting compositions: Tried to go to http://localhost:3001/index.html and verify that it is a Remotion project by checking if window.getStaticCompositions is defined.
However, the function was undefined, which indicates that this is not a valid Remotion project. Please check the URL you passed.
The page loaded contained the following markup:

Does this look like a foreign page? If so, try to stop this server.
    at innerSetPropsAndEnv (Z:\vscode\soundiclyvideomaker\node_modules\.pnpm\@remotion+renderer@4.0.57_react-dom@18.2.0_react@18.2.0\node_modules\@remotion\renderer\dist\set-props-and-env.js:102:15)        
    at process.processTicksAndRejections (node:internal/process/task_queues:95:5)
    at async setPropsAndEnv (Z:\vscode\soundiclyvideomaker\node_modules\.pnpm\@remotion+renderer@4.0.57_react-dom@18.2.0_react@18.2.0\node_modules\@remotion\renderer\dist\set-props-and-env.js:155:20)       
    at async innerSelectComposition (Z:\vscode\soundiclyvideomaker\node_modules\.pnpm\@remotion+renderer@4.0.57_react-dom@18.2.0_react@18.2.0\node_modules\@remotion\renderer\dist\select-composition.js:27:5)
```

> Running pnpm exec remotion render VideoComp out/testvideo.mp4 inside vscode's terminal window (using powershell, I'm on Windows) will throw that error even setting a port manually that's 100% free (I think it has to do with port forwarding from the new feature, or with code tunnels). Running it from a powershell with vscode closed works.

# Bug Report 🐛

![Screenshot 2023-10-27 at 12 09 53 AM](https://github.com/remotion-dev/remotion/assets/53830546/3bb2fdb5-83f7-4cfa-ab07-53ae28a3572a)

![Screenshot 2023-10-27 at 12 16 19 AM](https://github.com/remotion-dev/remotion/assets/53830546/f8ff000f-6d93-40f3-9fc2-21aa59414332)


In the docs, "three" entries are mentioned, but we actually have four entries, i.e, name, src, sizeInBytes and lastModified.

issue.title: Remotion Root issue with monorepos
issue.body:
I'm trying to add a remotion project to a monorepo created with nx. It has the following folder structure:
```
/organization
 ├── remotion
 │   ├── project.json (nx project configuration)
 │   ├── remotion.config.ts
 │   ├── src
 |   |   ├── index.ts (registerRoot entry point))
 │   ├── tsconfig.json (project specific ts configuration)
 ├── nx.json
 ├── node_modules (monorepo modules)
 ├── package.json (monorepo package.json)
 ├── package-lock.json
 ├── project.json
 └── tsconfig.base.json (base ts extended by projects)
```
I configured a "start" command in nx's configuration file (remotion/project.json) to start remotion studio:
```
"start": {
  "executor": "nx:run-commands",
  "options": {
    "command": "npx remotion studio remotion/src/index.ts --public-dir=remotion/public --config=remotion/remotion.config.ts"
  }
}
```
After executing it with ```nx run remotion:start``` I get the following error:
```
Could not find a tsconfig.json file in your project. Did you delete it? Create a tsconfig.json in the root of your project. Copy the default file from https://github.com/remotion-dev/template-helloworld/blob/main/tsconfig.json.
The root directory is: /organization
```
I still get the same error even if I change the command to execute inside the remotion project using the cwd option like this:
```
"start": {
  "executor": "nx:run-commands",
  "options": {
    "command": "npx remotion studio src/index.ts --public-dir=ublic --config=remotion.config.ts",
    "cwd ": "remotion"
  }
}
```
After a bit of debugging, it turns out that the [Remotion Root](https://www.remotion.dev/docs/terminology#remotion-root) is determined by the first package.json found in the parent directories. In my case, I have the package.json defined at the root of my workspace (or "monorepo"), but the root of the remotion project is in the ./remotion subfolder, so it's not being able to find the tsconfig.json file.

I was able to get the entry point and the public directory working by using the command options (as shown above), but there's no option to configure the remotion root. 

I'm not sure if there's any way to get around this issue. I've seen that the [findRemotionRoot](https://github.com/remotion-dev/remotion/blob/266d67d073cc1207261dd2aa2c018fb1499da155/packages/renderer/src/find-closest-package-json.ts#L22C14-L22C30) function first tries to find a package.json file and then falls back to the current working directory if it's not found.

Is there any reason for not using the current working directory as the remotion root instead of trying to find a package.json file first?
Would a CLI option such as --remotion-root be more suitable in this case?

Thanks

issue.title: Remotion Root issue with monorepos
issue.body:
I'm trying to add a remotion project to a monorepo created with nx. It has the following folder structure:
```
/organization
 ├── remotion
 │   ├── project.json (nx project configuration)
 │   ├── remotion.config.ts
 │   ├── src
 |   |   ├── index.ts (registerRoot entry point))
 │   ├── tsconfig.json (project specific ts configuration)
 ├── nx.json
 ├── node_modules (monorepo modules)
 ├── package.json (monorepo package.json)
 ├── package-lock.json
 ├── project.json
 └── tsconfig.base.json (base ts extended by projects)
```
I configured a "start" command in nx's configuration file (remotion/project.json) to start remotion studio:
```
"start": {
  "executor": "nx:run-commands",
  "options": {
    "command": "npx remotion studio remotion/src/index.ts --public-dir=remotion/public --config=remotion/remotion.config.ts"
  }
}
```
After executing it with ```nx run remotion:start``` I get the following error:
```
Could not find a tsconfig.json file in your project. Did you delete it? Create a tsconfig.json in the root of your project. Copy the default file from https://github.com/remotion-dev/template-helloworld/blob/main/tsconfig.json.
The root directory is: /organization
```
I still get the same error even if I change the command to execute inside the remotion project using the cwd option like this:
```
"start": {
  "executor": "nx:run-commands",
  "options": {
    "command": "npx remotion studio src/index.ts --public-dir=ublic --config=remotion.config.ts",
    "cwd ": "remotion"
  }
}
```
After a bit of debugging, it turns out that the [Remotion Root](https://www.remotion.dev/docs/terminology#remotion-root) is determined by the first package.json found in the parent directories. In my case, I have the package.json defined at the root of my workspace (or "monorepo"), but the root of the remotion project is in the ./remotion subfolder, so it's not being able to find the tsconfig.json file.

I was able to get the entry point and the public directory working by using the command options (as shown above), but there's no option to configure the remotion root. 

I'm not sure if there's any way to get around this issue. I've seen that the [findRemotionRoot](https://github.com/remotion-dev/remotion/blob/266d67d073cc1207261dd2aa2c018fb1499da155/packages/renderer/src/find-closest-package-json.ts#L22C14-L22C30) function first tries to find a package.json file and then falls back to the current working directory if it's not found.

Is there any reason for not using the current working directory as the remotion root instead of trying to find a package.json file first?
Would a CLI option such as --remotion-root be more suitable in this case?

Thanks

comment.body:
That did the trick for me. Thank you, Jonny.

Also, just for reference, I had to run the command from the remotion project (using the cwd nx option), so that remotion finds the empty package.json first, instead of the package.json placed at the root of the monorepo, as it was doing before.

issue.title: Split up `setPort()` option
issue.body:
Currrently the `Config.setPort()` option sets the port for the Remotion Studio but also for rendering.
Now that you render from within the studio that leads to a conflict.

We should split it up to `Config.setStudioPort()` and `Config.setRendererPort()`. `Config.setPort()` should get a `@deprecated` JSDoc command but for now set both ports still.

The `--port` flag should set the Studio port when running the `remotion studio` command, but the renderer port when using any other  command.

comment.body: @JonnyBurger I have full confidence in completing this. I would like to understand how the `remotion cli` works by working on this issue. Can you assign this issue to me?
